Sure, I'd be happy to provide some hypothetical examples of how multiple protocols could be used in each of the four application scenarios.

1. Smart HVAC Systems:

At the physical layer, the HVAC system may use Wi-Fi or BLE to communicate with temperature and humidity sensors, as well as with HVAC control units. This would enable the system to collect data from sensors and control HVAC units in real-time.

At the network layer, the HVAC system may use Zigbee or Z-Wave to create a mesh network of devices and route data between them. This would help to extend the range of the network and ensure that data is transmitted reliably.

At the application layer, the HVAC system may use MQTT to transmit data from sensors to the cloud-based platform where the data is analyzed and used to control the HVAC system. The platform may also use HTTP or HTTPS to provide a user interface for hotel staff to monitor and adjust the HVAC system settings.

2. Smart Lighting Systems:

At the physical layer, the lighting system may use Zigbee to communicate with occupancy and ambient light sensors, as well as with individual light fixtures. This would enable the system to collect data from sensors and control light fixtures in real-time.

At the network layer, the lighting system may use Wi-Fi or BLE to connect to the cloud-based platform where the data is analyzed and used to control the lighting system. This would help to ensure that data is transmitted reliably and securely.

At the application layer, the lighting system may use MQTT to transmit data from sensors to the cloud-based platform, as well as to receive commands from the platform to adjust the lighting levels. The platform may also use HTTP or HTTPS to provide a user interface for hotel staff to monitor and adjust the lighting system settings.
